pros: If you have imposter syndrome it’s a great job because literally no one will seem better than you.
cons: A cesspool of naturalized harassment, intellectual mediocrity, racism, homophobia and bureaucratic incompetence. Anyone who complains or points out any issues gets immediately bullied to death. Backstabbing is law. Trust no one. The inefficiency and lack of education of the employees is laughable. Diversity initiatives run by white people lol. Lecturers not allowed to fail students no matter how poor their performance (and 99% of their performance is very very very very low). A sense that the school attracts the very worst when it comes to students, lecturers and certainly management. Colleagues and students are scandalously incapable and hostile. Hard to believe an institution like this is allowed to exist in this country.

pros: There are lots of benefits of working for Brookes like a fairly good stable salary, cheaper bus travel, good pension benefits and staff groups (I enjoy being in the LGBTQ forum). There are lots of talks, cafes and libaries to take advantage of too.
cons: There needs to be better understanding of where to go if your team is not being managed well or better training for management. I have been in two positions at Brookes where my manager has used fear of humilation as a motivator for the team and, I have been doing work not in my job description ( taking on projects which are above my pay grade), due to low staff capaciy. However I have also been in another position prepandemic at Brookes with a brilliant supportive managment.

pros: A majority of the staff are professional, diligent, and pleasant to work with. Staff retention is good, as are opportunities for internal moves.
cons: Salaries aren't particularly high, and many posts have no prospects for promotion. Overmanagement can be a problem. There's a fear of change and innovation, and a real tendency to focus inwards. Bullying isn't unknown, unfortunately.

pros:
I have worked for Oxford Brookes for many years and seen a tremendous amount changes during that time.  Brookes is an organisation that doesn't stand still. 

Throughout my employment I have been encouraged and supported by my managers and the organisation to develop my skills so as to meet my career aspirations. These have included support to complete an MSc, in-house training and valuable secondment opportunities within Brookes. If you have the drive and desire to progress  your career and seek and take new work experiences and put time in the study and gain qualifications to support your career aspirations then my experience is that Brookes will support you.

Other forms of staff support include clear HR Policy and Procedures.  Additionally, there is also a Brookes People Awards scheme and a staff Feel Good Festival.

Having the opportunity to work in an organisation where there is such a passion for excellence makes me proud to be part of it.
cons: Shared offices can be noisy. But I can work from home on a project or find one of the many small work spaces and pods to work if I need to.

review_title: Always been proud to work for OBU...not anymore with recent restructuring.
pros: Dedicated staff that do whatever they can in their own ways to enhance the student experience despite adversity and unfit systems.
cons: Low morale due to restructuring in 2011/12, which was badly communicated and executed. IT infrastructure, especially for student support and record-keeping is outdated and does not fit half the student population that sits outside the three-year undergraduate students.

review_title: A company with good job prospects and opportunities to progress
pros:
A great team environment, where colleagues are only too pleased to help out and make new staff feel welcome.
Great facilities around campus including restaurants, Starbucks outlets and shops.
Plenty of opportunities for staff development 
Take a look, even if you don't work in education or for a university
A lot of investment being made in the estate with new buildings and refurbishment (currently ongoing)
cons: Some processes could be looked at and streamlined, only downside, the University is a large organisation and can be slow to change

pros:
Fish and chips on Fridays /nice view in the Terrace  restaurant
Brookes (trainee chefs) restaurant menu 
Modern campus (but is this what a university should be about?)
cons:
If you re joining as an academic expect to be turned into a low ranking clerk/admin.
Academics ruled by admin.staff
Desperate to please  students and seek their approval
Spoon-fed students (great way to prepare them for working /adult life I suppose)
Senior managers who have been here far too long (career-minded, resistant to change)
Short -term vision  & cost-focused

pros: Oxford Brookes is the 'other' university in Oxford. A factor which brings both advantages and difficulties for the institution. The city is beautiful and a great place to live. However it has a a high cost of living and house prices are exceedingly high in relation to lecturer wages. The tired university buildings are slowly being demolished to make way for a new campus. Generally a friendly and congenial place to work . The students are mostly of a good standard for what is, in effect, an ex poly, - though many of them are very much grade focused. Relatively few students show any passion for their chosen subject. The university does want to see research take off but it is not a strategic priority and it is unlikely to happen without proper strategic investment which is unlikely to be forthcoming..
cons:
The impression is that the senior management are remote and cold. Academics are not listened to or consulted about meaningful decisions regarding the university and its core policies - or at least that is the impression most of us get. Consultation is usually done as lip service when a decision has already been made. Obsessive restructuring and attempts at teaching 'innovation' - usually without an evidential basis for their effectiveness. Highly centralised academic management system which is often procedure-obsessed and frequently acts against the interest of students in ways which academics are unable to influence. 
Research takes very much a back foot.  Expect long working hours if one wants to have any research career of any kind -it gets pushed into the evenings and weekends.
The university frequently attracts high calibre academics but few of these last more than a few years once they realise how the place operates. Most are worn down by the petty bureaucracies, high workloads and appalling facilities. The library is terrible - lacking many mainstream journals. Ultimately the place is incompatible with being a serious researcher  Other issues are the lack of proper IT support -all of it is centralised and slow to respond and focused on teaching. There is little to no technical support for research. The university lacks a proper 'research culture' - there is no intellectual 'buzz' from working at the university - most departments have several members of lecturing staff that do no research at all, which doesn't help.

review_title: Trying to improve on a very tight budget, with limited success
pros:
In Oxford - good student town, Nice area for employees too.  Logistically well-placed in South of England with good road and rail links and Heathrow less than an hour away.
Generally friendly and cordial environment to work, but not much fun.  Good access to journals either directly or via agreement with Bodelean.  Ambitions to become more research-focused.  Good support for international students.  Good support for lecturers learning to teach.  Senior management seems to have a clear plan for the future, with new campus building in Gipsy Lane about to open later this year - looks very shiny.  Students are generally pleasant and polite, they seem to have a good social life and work hard, but only a small proportion seem to have any intellectual curiousity.  Most just want to jump through hoops, get a 1st/2:1, and then get a job.
cons:
Very long hours for lecturers who want to teach and do research too.  Severe lack of research-active staff of professorial rank to provide leadership for research-active junior faculty, and to facilitate success with external grant applications.  Higher than average staff turnover with strict recruitment moratorium currently in force on replacements, leading to ever higher workloads for remaining faculty and reduced time available for servicing needs of students.  Teaching very difficult over last few years due to noise and disruption from building works.  University spread over several geographically isolated campuses, making coordination difficult.  Quality and dedication of teaching staff highly variable.  Not much social interaction between teaching staff - no common rooms and very few after-work drinks. 
Strategic focus is entirely about increasing revenue by finding additional sources of income, as well as improving student satisfaction to maintain recruitment.  While the latter is laudable and has led to a more responsive and student-focused system, there still remain a lot of contributory factors that have nothing to do with quality of the lecturer or module leader.  The standard duration of all teaching sessions is 3 hours, making it challenging to maintain students' attention and enthusiasm for the entire duration.  Quality of teaching environment is highly variable, ranging from the modern, light, comfortable classrooms featured on the website and prospectus, to dingy, 1970's polytechnic-style rooms with uncomfortable plastic chairs that are not cleaned regularly enough.  These can become quite uncomfortable after 3 hours of a teaching session.

pros: Excellent local colleagues, very lucky to have forgiving student of service let downs!
cons: The University is becoming increasingly corporate, so focused on NSS which is crude and too broad ranging. Inventing many many more processes to deal with 'issues' which have been extrapolated rather than evidence; which unnecessarily sap time and take you away from students and other users.

pros: Excellent opportunities for personal and professional growth. Open to suggestions and will implement certain ideas. Celebrates certain staff for their contribution.
cons: Overly bureaucratic. Line management is either very excellent or very poor. Policies are often overlooked or ignored, especially when issues and problems with direct management are concerned. Seems very clique'y at times, very much 'not what you know, but who you know'.

pros: Flexible hours, usually you choose your shifts when it's convenient for you, for the phone campaign shifts are in the evening so it's great if you have classes at uni during the day.
cons: They payroll goes through monthly, so you have to have all your documents in by the end of the month and will only get paid the end of next month. It's annoying bur the hourly rate is really good.

pros: Great colleagues, Headington campus is beautiful - many trees and open spaces, fairly flexible working.
cons: Management have lost sight of University values.  Professional services staff are undervalued by senior management.  Too much change, too quickly.  Not enough time to come to terms with change or to get it right.

review_title: Good work life balance, great people
pros: Great work life balance - good holiday allowance, flexible hours. Great colleagues and friendly place to work
cons: Management decisions are slow and confusing. Pay is lower than same role at other institutions. Food on site is over priced. Progression can be a challenge with mid management positions rarely becoming available

review_title: A super friendly and supportive work place!
pros: The team were so friendly and welcoming. Everyone was incredibly supportive of one another and working in a team felt effortless with everyone involved. They were all very encouraging and helped you challenged yourself in a positive way.
cons: There isn't really anything negative to say about working on the new student welcome team at Oxford Brookes. The job itself is very full-on but I see that as a positive.
